docs.lead_paragraph: Some nursing home operators are closing facilities and turning to managed care, which is provided at adult day-care centers and patients’ homes and can save money for the government.

headline.seo: Managed Care Keeps the Frail Out of Nursing Homes
headline.main: A Shift From Nursing Homes to Managed Care at Home
headline.print_headline: A Shift From Nursing Homes To Managed Care at Home

docs.abstract: Nursing home operators in New York State, faced with rising health care costs and shrinking Medicare and Medicaid financing, are closing facilities and turning to managed care at adult day-care centers and patients' homes; newer model, although stemming from necessity, is seen by many experts as less expensive than traditional nursing homes while providing better medical outcomes for the elderly.
docs.snippet: Some nursing home operators are closing facilities and turning to managed care, which is provided at adult day-care centers and patients’ homes and can save money for the government.

byline.contributor: Robert Pear and Christopher Reeve contributed reporting.

docs.lead_paragraph: A program created to help insurance-seekers in Texas cut through the complexities of federal health care reforms is shutting down in April, years before the law goes into full effect.

headline.seo: Texas to Shut Consumer Health Assistance Program
headline.main: State to Close Program on Federal Health Law
headline.print_headline: State to Close Program On Federal Health Law

docs.abstract: At the CNN debate in Arizona, the Republican contenders dodged a question about birth control, and accused the president of attacking religious freedom.

headline.main: Study Tests Claims of Republican Candidates' Debt Plans

docs.abstract: A centrist budget-watchdog group, the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, is punching trillion-dollar holes in the claims of Republican presidential candidates that they would rein in the mounting federal debt if elected, according to an analysis to be released on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Hollywood, there are untold screenwriters, actors, directors and others invisibly struggling to keep their homes.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Hilary de Vries holds Hollywood, for all its glamor, has endured its share of the economic downturn and foreclosure crisis; says much of the suffering occurs out of view, as actors, directors and writers go bankrupt and lose their homes while attempting to maintain the appearances that come with a life in show business.
docs.snippet: In Hollywood, there are untold screenwriters, actors, directors and others invisibly struggling to keep their homes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Occasionally in the coming weeks and months, The Agenda will introduce you to small-business owners who are wrestling with how to provide health insurance to their employees. Over time, we hope to delve into all aspects of a crucial decision - not just managing the costs but sorting out benefit packages, weighing alternatives, and dealing with insurers and brokers. Along the way, we hope to get a better understanding of how the 2010 health-care legislation will, or won't, affect small businesses. Today we meet Ann Gish, who designs high-end bed linens from offices in Manhattan. As we proceed with this series, we'd like to hear from you. What questions would you like us to ask of the business owners we profile? Do you have an interesting health insurance story to tell? Please drop us a line.

headline.main: Trying to Cope With Confusion About Health Insurance Plans

docs.abstract: You're the Boss blog presents first in a series of posts about small-business owners who are wrestling with how to provide health insurance to their employees; features Ann Gish, owner of Ann Gish Inc. Photo (S)2
